title: Emmet - a perf hooligan?
body: The top 5 of extensions blocking the extension host process has a newcomer and that's emmet. In 1.31.1 it was top 20, with 1.32.3 it 2nd with 26037 hangs over 5 seconds. I don't have a profile at hand and I also don't use emmet but looking at its implementation might explain it, esp since it doesn't do things in LSP-style but in-proc, e.g probably slowing everything down when a file is large/huge

title: How can a FS provider determine the correct workspace folder root when it recevies a call

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
Consider a FS provider that wants to show the content of a zip file. It therefore registers a provider for a schema `zip`. It also allows to open a zip by using a folder uri `zip:///home/dbaeumer/myzip.zip`. 

When the FS provider receives the first call for an URI (which can look like `zip:///home/dbaeumer/myzip.zip/.vscode`) it needs to know which part of the URI is the root folder to open the zip. Searching for something like `name.zip` doesn't work since a folder could also be named `myDir.zip`. I see the following options:

- we guaruntee that the first call is always a stat call with the root folder.
- we guaruntee that the `workspace.workspaceFolders` is containing the root before the first call. We also guaruntee that:
  - if a folder gets added a workspace folder add event is sent before the first call to the FS provider.
  - if a folder gets removed it would be nice if no more calls to the FS provider are made. But an extensions could handle this gracefully knowing it has to.
- we always pass in the root to the FS provider calls.
- we add some `handle` & `unhandle` methods to the FS provider which are called if the provider should handle new roots or roots it handled disappear.
- something else.

I relied on the first one so far which actually was a false assumption. But to implement that correctly I need to know which assumptions I can make that hold.

My preference would either be the workspace folder array and event correctness or handle and unhandle on the FS provider.

title: File Provider: unable to preserve symbolic links via move/copy across providers
body:
With the new file service we can support move/copy across file system providers for files and folders. However, if one of the items is a symbolic link, there is currently no way to re-create such a link on the target provider. 

In node.js terms there is a method called [`symlink`](https://nodejs.org/docs/v10.2.0/api/fs.html#fs_fs_symlink_target_path_type_callback). 

I think conceptually we would need new API such as `link(source, target)` and then providers have to deal with the quirks.

On top of that we also need a way to resolve the target of the link, otherwise we cannot make a decision how to restore it.

Bottom line: I think it only makes sense to preserve symlinks if they are self contained in the data that is being moved/copied, not when pointing outside.

title: Call hierarchy: use different icons to express semantics of call graph nodes
body:
testing #71083:

Since all nodes of a call graph are functions, representing them with a function icon does not provide additional information:

![2019-03-26_17-01-15](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1898161/55013216-f56bcb00-4fe8-11e9-9a07-97b75f902ad9.png)

Instead we could use different icons to express the following semantics:
- an icon for the "peeked" function (root of the tree). This could be the icon you are using today.
- a strong (bold) up-arrow-like icon (↖) for direct callers
- a dimmed up-arrow-like icon for indirect callers

Another dimension to encode in the icon could be information about the caller being local or external.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Found testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/67744

All testing was done in the explorer view.

I turned on NVDA and saw that the list keyboard navigation changed.

When I turned off NVDA, I expected that the list keyboard navigation would go back to the new filtering behavior. It did not.

I reloaded. It still stayed on the simple navigation. 

I had to fully restart VS Code before the navigation went back to the filtering behavior. If VS Code can automatically switch to simple when there is a screen reader (no restart) then it should be able to switch back.

title: Mac电脑三个手指点击查询单词操作错误
body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.18.0 (dcee2202709a4f223185514b9275aa4229841aa7, 2017-11-08T12:32:39.870Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
EditorConfig|Edi|0.11.1
vscode-simple-icons|Lau|1.11.2
githistory|don|0.4.0
vstortoise|flo|1.2.2
Python-autopep8|him|1.0.2
easy-icons|jam|0.3.1
webpack|jer|2.1.3

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.新建文本，输入特定文字，比如下面的：

```js
.git
.DS_Store
```
